I'm going to sound absurdly pessimistic here, but this whole video is so "same-y" to me. It's seemingly the same results from AMD as we got last generation, with the XTX cards. They do well, but fall just short of the mark in comparison. I completely understand (and actually love) that gamers are able to get "mostly" affordable cards, even if they'll be flying off shelves, and scalped for a slightly higher cost, at least for a long while, but AMD just doesn't seem to want to "beat" Nvidia, and that's really a shame. AMD has come SO far in the CPU world, where, for many many years, they were almost completely out done by Intel (Except in the case of workstation, but I'm talking about gamers here.) and now AMD is even starting to hold dominance in the CPU world, even over Intel, which I absolutely LOVE to see, because MORE competition makes the market BETTER, and drives larger improvements from all sides. The problem, is that, from what I've seen last generation, and this generation, is that AMD just wants to be the affordable, but not quite "amazing" card. They just want to be the average card, that isn't as good, but more people have access to it. I don't like that, because, ultimately, at the end of the day, everyone 'wants' the top of the line Nvidia card. If every gamer were given an unlimited budget for a gaming rig, they'd almost all surely buy the 5090 right now, and that kinda sucks, because while Nvidia sits atop the mountain of performance, AMD doesn't seem to be making a run for the crown, and that makes a stagnant market. It really ultimately hurts both AMD and Nvidia in this case, because Nvidia (As we've seen with both the 40 and 50 series) have been having some serious issues, with the power connectors, and horrible, horrible launches, making an $2,000 MSRP card almost immediately cost $5,000. I want to see AMD make a REAL card. A card that REALLY shoots for the top, EVEN if it comes at a much higher price tag. I want to see AMD make Nvidia sweat. Make Nvidia nervous. Make Nvidia have to CARE about their products again.

9:47 Seems like the fps limits are borked for DLSS, you probably should disable gsync and vsync and disable fps limit when doing a framegen test.
There are some games where the fps limits don't work correctly or do their own thing.
For example in Monster Hunter Wilds, while you never enabled framegen, fps limits works correctly.
But if you enable framegen, then in game fps limit 60 will equal to 120 of total fps, also that's how it's listed in the config.ini file. When you disable framegen it limits to what you see.
But with gpu driver fps limit you have to set it based on the total fps instead of real fps, and when you disable framegen, then it will break and limit to half of the value instead so if you have a 120 fps limit in gpu drivers it will be 60 instead, until you restart the game and don't toggle framegen on and off on next run.
In 1 game I had to set in drivers to 180 fps limit, so I could get 90 fps limit in the game, otherwise the 90 fps limit limited to 45 instead, regardless if framegen was on or not.
The in game fps limits seem to be so far reverse of gpu driver fps limits, if they're bugged or don't describe properly what they're doing.
In indiana jones for example, while you're in the menus, the framegen doesn't even work until you close out of the menu, so you might be sometimes like is it even working, or is some fps limit nonsense going on.

I got messed over by NewEgg and/or Gigabyte this morning. After staying up super late and waking up super early, spamming online stores for inventory to appear and subsequently attempting to purchase a couple different $600 9070XT models only to receive an out-of-stock notification during processing, I was finally able to purchase the ‚ÄúGIGABYTE Gaming Radeon RX 9070 XT 16GB GDDR6 PCI Express 5.0 x16 Graphcis Card GV-R9070XTGAMING OC-16GD.‚Äù

I received three emails from NewEgg this morning:
1. 8:29AM ‚ÄúWe received your Trade-in Form‚Äù

The raw BOM cost of the 9070XT is basically no more than the BOM cost of the 7800XT which had an MSRP of $499 and regularly sold for $450. Sure I get that 4nm is ever so slightly more expensive than 5nm but at the same time GDDR6 prices have come down, other costs like shipping and general inflation might have also increased but I think AMD could have been more aggressive if they really really wanted to, but $599 in the current climate of basically 'no competition from Nvidia' is good enough and will sell very well. The 5070Ti is certainly not worth $300-400 more than the 9070XT, but AMD needs to be really careful because if Nvidia sorts themselves out (this could happen if it's yield issues or something else we don't know) and start to fill shelves with $749 cards then 100% AMD can not look to charge $650-700+ for this card which has been rumoured once all the MSRP cards are sold. 
The 5070Ti is better in every single way, but it's just not '$300 better', but most buyers including myself would happy pay $50-100 more for better overall performance, better power usage, better ray tracing, better and wider DLSS support, Reflex, HDR, better encoding quality, better support in content creation apps, Cuda, the list goes on. I genuinely had my heart set on a 5070Ti this year (I've not owned Nvidia in about 20 years!) but the performance increase wasn't that impressive and the pricing/available is just ridiculous. Thankfully AMD looks to have got their sh!t together this generation, it's a solid card, decent performance, they are addressing their shortcomings and they have *currently* priced this card where it needs to be in the market we have right now. But honestly, AMD can't go north of $600 long term as this card simply isn't good enough against a $749 5070Ti, imo.

I would *love* to see AMD get ahead of nvidia for a more reasonable price point, but until they deliver a top-tier gpu that can best stuff like the 5090 so that devs will really pay attention and develop for the underlying apis, and definitively show off as "the best", they're going to be looked at as second class cards.  Most of the ai models and hardware fp16/fp32 gpu compute acceleration paradigms are very specifically written for CUDA, making them not work on AMD cards - including ai models, media apps, and specific proprietary apis in games.  the last time I bought an amd card was a looong time ago, it was a 7970x and I was soooo bummed when I couldn't get the physx effects my friends were seeing. - what we really need is an open, unified low level api that everybody can get behind.  something simple, optimized, and documented enough that in 20 years we can emulate it on more commodity hardware.  stop with all this proprietary api manure, and create an even playing field for everyone to innovate on.  of course the liklihood of this happening, without external regulation, is worse than buying a winning lottery ticket, but *shrug*

Gotta critique them on the AFMF part. That was a horrid example and a very disingenuous way to talk about it, even for a short part. AFMF is good, its great actually, and as someone who has used it since it's first beta years ago, it has come a long way. Again, as someone who has used this feature in dozens of games from beta to the 2.0 release, it NEVER, let me say it again, NEVER LOOKS AS BAD AS WHAT THEY JUST SHOWED lmao. AFMF may exist so AMD can say 'WE have FG in more games' but they do, and it actually works. Cyberpunk, RDR2, Mafia 3, Guardians of the Galaxy, Jedi Fallen Order, and GTA V (Legacy) are just a few of the MANY singleplayer games I play with AFMF on and its fantastic. Cyberpunk is a great example here because for all of the updates it has received since Phantom Liberty, somehow CDPR STILL cannot be bothered to implement FSR3.1 and allow FSR-FG to run with other upscalers, something many modern games have had for a while. Running Cyberpunk @ 1440p Ultra (No RT whatsoever) with XESS 1.31 on Quality + using AFMF & RIS (Radeon Image Sharpening @ 100%) nets a MUCH better gaming experience than with the native FSR implementation in that game. It's clearer, smoother, and no artifacts that one can see just playing the game, a 160FPS experience (80ish without AFMF), instead of zooming in 300x and slowing the game down by 75% to say 'LOOK, SEE THAT SPEC, AFMF SUCKS!' which is precisely why HUB lost me as a viewer. I feel like we're seeing a split in the market where NVIDIA is going all-in on the industrial AI market and leaving gaming out of it due to the higher margins in the AI space due to a market rush.

AMD seems to be saying "okay we'll put just enough AI investment in to match NVIDIA's feature set, but we're going to focus on rendering performance and encoding."

It's honestly a good thing since that means the better gaming and video workstation cards are going to be less affected by the AI drought we're seeing. Let NVIDIA move away from the market and expand the potential market share for Intel and AMD.

Intel having a motivation to try and make an enthusiast card will be really good for the market; AMD backing out of the enthusiast market might be a bit of a red herring given that they'll still be putting out workstation cards of equivalent performance. I suspect if Intel actually made a gaming-capable enthusiast card AMD would quickly re-spec a W series to get a 32gb monster out (that would cost like $2,700 but hey, it'd beat the 5090 in 8k performance with that massive VRAM.

I would like to bring up what a different YouTuber (I can't remember who) brought up in a short: Using an older HDMI and Display Port spec REALLY does not matter on this mid-tier of graphics cards. That YouTuber made the point that, at this price point and performance level, these cards are not going to put out the frame rates in most games to truly utilize the full bandwidth of the new HDMI and Display Port standards, so why sweat that detail? And that is a valid point, if you have the money for a high refresh rate, super high end 4K display that requires the newer versions of those ports, you are not wasting your time and money on looking at let alone buying a RTX 5070 Ti or an AMD Radeon RX 9070 XT, and even the RTX 4080-5080. Those people go straight to the new Titan series cards of the current era, the RTX 4090-5090 cards, when they can find them. To me, without using the gimmicks, AMD has closed the gap hugely on Nvidia in the mid-tier. And, IF the price points stick even remotely close to MSRP, I would be happy to upgrade from my RTX 2080 Super to a Radeon RX 9070 XT, versus either a RTX 5080 or 5070 Ti. I don't need 4K gaming, and AMD just made a card with enough rasterization performance to play 99.9% of my game collection just fine maxed out at 2560x1440 and 100Hz, for $600.00 MSRP. It would do ray tracing in the games I have with it as an option WAY better than my current card, and I would never need to touch FSR. I can't care about newer games right now, there is nothing out or coming in the near future that I care to own, when I have a collection now I can never hope to complete.

 TL:DR Bravo to AMD for finally making a mid-tier card to compete with Nvidia, and under cut their stupidity and lies. If pricing stays stable (doubt it) I just may have to finally upgrade again, and back to an all AMD configuration.

There was a day I would come home to play games. My computer would turn on, the fans would spool up, and the fans would sing to me quiet songs of content happiness. Those were beautiful days, but all things must come to an end. I noticed that my 1080Ti looked worse for wear one day. I thought nothing of it, it happens I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôll be okay. Days went by, weeks, months‚Ä¶until finally it broke. In that moment I was in a panic. A friend to me, near and dear had crashed. Fallen and unable to get up. I quickly rushed to the repair center and asked for assistance, I couldn‚Äôt let it die. The repairman reassured me everything would be fine. Days went by and my thoughts were consumed at school. Until finally I got a call with my heart racing. Only relieved when I was told the operation was success. At the end of day I was Uber‚Äôed (mom) to the shop and able to pick up my dear friend. I re-assured myself things would be okay. For the next few years this was a cycle. Crash, repair, break, fix over and over and over again. Until one day I had been told ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, I can‚Äôt fix this. It‚Äôs too old and worn out‚Äù. My heart stopped, and my entire life flashed before my eyes. Friends, family, all of them were unavailable. For years I reached to many others but could never find the success I needed to form that relationship I needed. So I would return home to my small dusty messed up computer. Finishing the day with some simple free to play games and YouTube. Yet that day was a countdown, until I could never hold that chance again. Years continued to go by. New friends, new relationships, girls. Yet I would always come home to my trusty computer that I built with my own hands. Trial and error, success and failure, but it was mine. Got a new job, and made more money but in the end the 1080Ti was mine and mine alone. *Tears start to form* Today though, marks a new day. A day it can finally rest. A day it can finally see peace. I looked at it one last time before I clocked on ‚ÄúPre-Order‚Äù. In my mind, I saw myself as a child looking at myself as a a man now. No words were spoken between my past self, and I who I am now but I know what was said. My 10 year old self said me ‚Äúit‚Äôs okay, you did well‚Äù I cried in that moment as I saw the 9070ti one screen. I don‚Äôt know if I ever really said the words, but I know I thought of them. I looked at my 1080Ti one last time. A little dusty, old, and worn out. I looked at it and said ‚ÄúYou know I‚Äôm proud of you‚Ä¶right?‚Äù So I plugged it in one last time, and played a final time with it as our last dance. A token of brothers, a long standing relationship that withstood the test of time itself. Before I closed to case I made for it when I was a little boy and put it to rest one last time.
-
May AMD be merciful on this weathered old soul. For I know not how many more days I have left, before I too may rest and never wake up again.

It really does make me sad that the A.I. compute processing clout is used to such an ineffective and poor frame amping method, I mean Sony produced their own FPGA accelerated rolling-scan algorithm for almost 1:1 static:dynamic motion-resolution over 10 years ago, meaning you get for all intents perfect frame-pacing and timings at just 60Hz on a sample & hold display (in this case an OLED display, aka RGB-OLED), yes the latency isn't ideal with 60Hz S&H modulation, but it's a damn sight better than the 100ms+ we see with these A.I. methods, if Sony was capable of pulling that of with an FPGA, just imagine what the so-called graphical rendering experts could muster with all that compute, GPU & VRAM capacity. 

Imagine if AMD collaborated with Blur Busters and incorporated their incredible rolling-scan algorithm into their GPU via bare-metal, along with an SRAM frame-buffer, almost 0ms MPRT with just 60 FPS on the 500Hz OLED monitors, or 1ms MPRT with a 360Hz OLED & 60 FPS, and sub 4ms MPRT for 240Hz, immaculate artifact free perfectly paced frames at as low as 60 FPS, and 120 FPS with this tech would feel incredible, that much compute clout could manage almost perfect raster-scan modulation, maybe even dual raster-scan (top/bottom to middle), just imagine 8K HDR-Rolling-Scan on a 16:10 aspect 32 inch RGB-OLED (RGB-stripe for a massively increased subpixel-resolution, about two thirds higher to be exact), this would give you almost current flagship smartphone level subpixel-resolution, just imagine that amount of mega-pixel clarity even with full-motion (every 8K frame 100% resolved at 60 FPS+), current OLED displays barely manage 10-20% of their respective advertised resolutions with 60-120 FPS.

The only thing AMD needs to do now is refine their drivers and get better support from developers. I had a 7700 XT, and while it worked great in most cases, it struggled in some niche areas I actually enjoy‚Äîareas where my old 1080 Ti had no issues.

One major problem I encountered was with Steam Link and other home streaming services like Parsec and Moonlight. The 7700 XT has a known issue where streaming will freeze (though the game itself keeps running), forcing you to restart the stream. This happened anywhere from once an hour to every 10 minutes, which was incredibly frustrating.

Another issue was with Diablo 4. Many users, including myself, reported that after a loading screen, the game would show a black screen with only the UI elements, making it unplayable. On top of that, I experienced serious stuttering and freezing, which Diablo 4 is known for, but it was way worse on my 7700 XT compared to my 1080 Ti.

I also had problems with Hogwarts Legacy and Elden Ring. Something‚Äîeither RTX or FSR, I‚Äôm not sure which‚Äîbugged out, causing serious stuttering and screen blinking. I suspect it was a combination of FSR, RTX, and faulty drivers, because after a driver update, the issue disappeared.

Speaking of drivers, I had the 7700 XT for 3‚Äì4 months, and in that time, I only saw one driver update. Meanwhile, NVIDIA releases driver updates so frequently it‚Äôs almost annoying.

After dealing with all of this, I finally gave up, sold the 7700 XT, and bought a 4070 Super‚Äîand honestly, I‚Äôm pretty happy with it.

I feel like a lot of videos are saying FSR 4 isn't quite as good as DLSS 4, but my eyes are actually seeing something totally different. 

When in motion, I'm noticing FSR4 has better image stability in a lot of areas, while DLSS 4 has a bit more detail when things are slowed down. Like if I was looking at a character standing still, I'd be able to notice slightly more detail on their clothes with DLSS, but then if you make them move quickly or fire off some particles effect ability, I see more image breakup & artifacts with DLSS as well.

The problem with the high end GPU for AMD was Navi41 and Navi42 failed on the first implementation too late into the design phase.  The problem was fixed for UDNA (RDNA5), but AMD wouldn't be able to fix Navi41 and Navi42 in a reasonable time.  The only way AMD can deliver a "high end" GPU is if AMD had sufficient work done for a non-leaked chip, like Navi43 for example, that was designed similar to Navi31's single compute die + multiple memory controller dies.  The rumors of a 32GB "gaming" card could be anything from a special Navi48 die with double VRAM, dual Navi48, or AMD had work on another RDNA4 die that wasn't leaked.  If AMD had a back-up high end GPU, why not push it instead of Navi48?  AMD expected the RTX 50 series to be great, and thus such a chip still would not make sense.  Regardless of such speculation, the best chance for an RDNA4 high end GPU is a mid-generation release, if AMD thinks it is viable.  Given that stores need supply and how much hardware troubles Nvidia is having for their RTX 50 series launch, conditions may "now" be viable for the back-up high end RDNA4 GPU.

Given how badly the RTX 50 series launched, will these problems influence how soon or how late the RTX 60 series comes?  Jensen should be upset with how much the entire internet is mocking his CES presentation of the RTX 50 series.  It is too late to unlaunch the RTX 50 series and delay it 6 months to fix everything.  Not only should Nvidia be fixing the RTX 50 series, they need to evaluate the risk that the RTX 60 series could repeat all of these mishaps.

Positive POV: It's 150 dollars cheaper than the 5070ti, it has improved raytracing, solid performance per dollar, actually in stock, solid AI catchup to Nvidia and it beats the standard 5070 in performance for basically the same price.

Negative POV: It still struggles in the one market AMD has decided to place all their cards in, the mid-range. It doesn't even beat Nvidia in Nvidia's weakest generational uplift yet. If there ever was a chance for AMD to catch up or beat Nvidia in performance, this was it. This was their chance, but they just couldn't do it. It draws a lot more power then the 5070ti, still sits 8-19% behind Nvidia in raytracing and they are absolutely cooked if Nvidia drops prices anywhere close to 600.

This is overall a useable win, but AMD should have slammed the 5070ti in performance if they really wanted the marketshare. You're paying for a graphics card half a generation behind for 150 dollars less, worth it? Maybe.

Who is out there running text generation using ONNX with DirectML??? I get you want to get a CUDA agnostic benchmark, but there is no way that a 4070 Ti with half the memory bandwidth of a 7900XTX manages almost double the performance in text generation in any real world scenario.

edit: edit: RED FLAG! I looked up the UL Procyon documentation, their scoring formula and which quants they are running. Now if they use INT4 with sparsity, then these test favor nVidia... except the 7900XTX has so much more raw FP16 and memory bandwidth, its AI TOPS should be competitive in dense INT4 compared to the 4070 and 3080. Yet they lose horribly. Why? Their scoring equation divides a "constant value" by the time to first token to calculate their "score" ‚Äîif time to first token takes dozens of seconds to minutes, then maybe this would be a balanced test, but it don't‚Äîit takes less then 1 second across all their prompt, it's basically a multiplier, because they use a very small context window (2k) while their entire phi-3.5 benchmark take maybe 1-2 minutes in total to complete 7 prompts. 

GPU A (*cough*4090*cough*) can complete the Phi-3.5-mini benchmark is less than 50 seconds, with a average TTFT of around 0.25s, scoring 5000 points! But if GPU B has an average TTFT of 0.50s (adding 1.75 seconds total in the full benchmark); this would instantly halve their score. GPU B would have to generate double the tokens/s and complete the test in half the time to overcome this discrepancy in (memory) latency to get an equal score, despite being obviously better in such a case.

To give you an idea of how much this TTFT part of their scoring equation biases the test, and another major RED FLAG, is the 9070 score; RDNA4 should perform 4-8 times better in int4 OPs than RDNA3 architecturally, and the 9070's have more AI TOPS than the 5070's. They should generating more tokens/second in theory, especially in a benchmark that isn't using CUDA. How much more? About 50%. Yet, it's the 5070's that score 50% higher! And they lose to the 7900 XTX also. The only advantage the XTX have over the 9070 is higher memory bandwidth, yet memory bandwidth doesn't seem to determine the outcome of this benchmark anywhere else.
